posts.post_content: The life gain you can get from one of these is so much it should be noteworthy. Pair with felidar sovereign and you can win inside of only a turn or two of playing the felidar alongside a dawnglow infusion. It might be vanilla life gain, but its double x cost vanilla life gain, in a mana accel and mana boosting color. With garruk wildspeaker untapping two of your lands that are enchanted by something like fertile ground, you could play dawnglow infusion for 10+ around mid game, netting you 20. I can't foresee any game that it would be bad to be regaining 20 life during your turn.
posts.html:
The life gain you can get from one of these is so much it should be noteworthy. It might be vanilla life gain, but its double x cost vanilla life gain, in a mana accel and mana boosting color. With garruk wildspeaker untapping two of your lands that are enchanted by something like fertile ground, you could play dawnglow infusion for 10+ around mid game, netting you 20. I can't foresee any game that it would be bad to be regaining 20 life during your turn.

posts.post_content:
In most cases, this will grant you 2(X-1) life in a W/G deck.  
Not a bad deal i guess for lifegain.  
  
Edit: Sorry Jagyr, with X i did not refer to the rules text on the card, i was regarding this as an effect that costs X and grants you life. In your example you had eight mana in total in your mana pool an gained 14 life, that makes 2(8-1) = 14.

Posted By: Guest1467942152 (11/14/2008 1:27:38 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
No, it would grant you 2X life. Say you've got 3 plains, 5 forests. Tap them all for mana. X=7. Dawnglow Infusion checks to see if you spent G on X. You did, so you gain 7 life. Then it checks to see if you spent W on X. You did, so you gain 7 again. Total gain of 14 :)  
  
It's easier than the rules text makes it seem. I was just playing in an online game and cast this spell with the above set up; that is, I had 5xG and 3xW in my mana pool, so X=7. My opponent insisted that I only gained 8 life...I could not for the life of me figure out how he was doing his math. He opted to quit the game instead of explaining.
posts.html:

posts.post_content:
A simple reference diagram:  
Mana Spent / Single Color Life Gain / Double Color Life Gain  
1 / 0 / 0  
2 / 1 / 2  
3 / 2 / 4  
4 / 3 / 6  
5 / 4 / 8  
6 / 5 / 10  
7 / 6 / 12  
8 / 7 / 14  
infinity / infinity / nfinity

4 / 3 / 6
5 / 4 / 8
6 / 5 / 10
7 / 6 / 12
8 / 7 / 14

Posted By: fanofmagic (6/30/2010 5:43:32 AM)
Rating:

posts.post_content: [Heroes' Reunion](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Heroes' Reunion) is generally better for these colors. It only costs 2 for 7 life, while with this you need to spend 5 mana to gain one more life. Unless you have insane mana ramp, and in that case there are better uses for it (unless you have a [Felidar Sovereign](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Felidar Sovereign) out). [Rest for the Weary](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Rest for the Weary) is also better, IMO.
posts.html:
Heroes' Reunion is generally better for these colors. It only costs 2 for 7 life, while with this you need to spend 5 mana to gain one more life. Unless you have insane mana ramp, and in that case there are better uses for it (unless you have a Felidar Sovereign out). Rest for the Weary is also better, IMO.
